title.value: From Physics to Sentience: Deciphering the Semantics of the Free-Energy Principle and Evaluating its Claims
title.justification: Title present at the top of the paper and in the arXiv citation.
title.quote: From Physics to Sentience: Deciphering the Semantics of the Free-Energy Principle and Evaluating its Claims

extractions.description: This paper provides technical comments and critical evaluation of the claims made in the target article 'Path integrals, particular kinds, and strange things' by Karl Friston et al. The authors address various conceptual and terminological issues emphasizing the need for precise semantics to improve clarity, rigor, and applicability in FEP-based formalisms.

type.justification: The paper primarily focuses on theoretical critiques and conceptual clarifications rather than empirical data or experiments.
type.quote: In this spirit of constructive feedback, we submit a few technical comments on some of the matters that appear to require further attention, in order to improve the clarity, rigour, and applicability of this framework.

name.justification: The paper discusses topics related to neuroscience such as the Free-Energy Principle, sentience, and consciousness.
name.quote: The Free-Energy Principle (FEP) has been adopted in a variety of ambitious proposals that aim to characterize all adaptive, sentient, and cognitive systems within a unifying framework.

name.justification: The paper focuses on theoretical aspects and critiques related to Free-Energy Principle in neuroscience.
name.quote: Judging by the amount of attention it has received from the scientific community, the FEP has gained significant traction in these pursuits.

name.justification: The paper delves into topics related to cognitive systems, sentience, and consciousness.
name.quote: The Free-Energy Principle (FEP) has been adopted in a variety of ambitious proposals that aim to characterize all adaptive, sentient, and cognitive systems within a unifying framework.
